text:
[APPLAUSE] OK. Well, it's great to see so
many familiar faces and so many new faces today.
And at least you're smiling now. So that's a good sign, too. Maybe I can give a good talk.

A lot of you might be wondering
about these books that are strewn on the
floor in the front. This is part of a
Christmas tradition.

All through the year, I keep
getting copies of my books

that are like they are
new printing came out. And so they give me a book
so that I can check it.

Or a new translation
came out, and they send me two copies of the
translation and I only need one.

And so I bring the
extra copies with me and they're sitting
here this year.

So some of them are
in Chinese, Japanese. Most of them are in English.

And there's also a couple
of real collector's items,

tech reports from when Metafont
was new, and things like that.

So anyway, I had
multiple copies of stuff. And this is my way to do better
than put it in the recycle bin.

I'm going to sit down
in a minute-- oh, yeah. There's a rule, though. First of all only
one to a customer.

So if you need two of them, you
and your friend each get one.

[CHUCKLES] And the other one is if you ask
a particularly good question

during the talk, then
I'm going to mention that you get first choice
before somebody else.

Because otherwise, you might
only get one of the other ones

that you didn't
want to read anyway. But anyway, those
are the ground rules.

One to customer,
and then if anybody does ask a good question,
then they get priority.

And by the way, that
means that you are allowed to ask questions as I talk.

OK. Now I'm going to sit down
because I'm an old man.

I've got a lot to say
and I hope I can get it all out in the right order.

When I was a grad student-- hey, we got people
standing in the back there.

There are some empty seats
in the front, not a heck

lot of them, I guess. So when I was a grad student,
my advisor, Marshall Hall,

was the world's foremost
authority on permutations. And I took his class and--

I didn't really understand
his lectures that well, but I wrote down
everything he said. And then the problem was to
find a permutation of his words

that would make
sense afterwards. [CHUCKLE] Well, I'm going to try to give
the right permutation today. But if I don't,
well, you might have

to watch the video
and replay it. The title as you can see, way
at the bottom is dancing cells.

And as Pax mentioned,
my talk five years ago

was called Dancing Links. And also in the year
2000 when the whole thing

was kind of brand new. I also had an amusing on
YouTube called Dancing Links.

And yeah, I watched
them and I'm still not too embarrassed about
what I said then.

But actually, there's
a lot of good news because we've improved
dancing links now

to something that has the
jazzy name dancing cells.

But basically, this talk
is about data structures,

and so were the two talks before
that were called dancing links. In other words, the
way to represent

information in a computer and
the structure between items

of data is called the
data structures problem. And the old timers like
me, in our [INAUDIBLE],

we used to think that
all the important data structures were well
understood by 1970 or 1980.

And so no need to
learn anything more. But what I'm talking
about today is something

that I learned three
years ago, and I could have learned 10 years ago
if I looked the right place.

So and I'll get
into the details.

But the whole story starts with
one of the first really great

books of computer science. I don't know if anybody
remembers this one?
Aho, Hopcroft, and Ullman. Hands, anybody know this book.

Here's one. A few. Yeah, OK. Yeah, we got 5%. Anyway, so this book came out
almost exactly 50 years ago.

And it had this exercise
on page 71, I think it was.

See if we can zoom
in right here, OK?

So exercise 2.12. And it has an asterisk,
means advanced--

"develop a technique to
initialize an entry of a matrix to zero the first
time it is accessed,

thereby eliminating the order
v squared time to initialize

an adjacency matrix of a graph." And then it gives a hint
as to how to do that.

And this exercise-- I mean,
in my copy of the book, in the back cover, I noticed
pages that really surprised me.

And the first one
was exercise 2.12-- uninitialized memory. Well, so what's that all about?

Well, let's suppose we have
a huge array in memory.

And in those days, a huge array
meant more than 1,000 or more

than 10,000. But now, just imagine,
we have some array that has a few billion elements
or something like that.

And it's all filled with
something-- random bits

basically. We don't have any
idea what's in it. But we would still like to
use the computer's ability

to do random access. So we want to access
something and we

want to work it out
so that if I want to store things in this memory
without initializing it.
So the first time I--

so maybe-- here's
element 3142 for example.

And I want to store
something in position 3142.

So I want this to be
reliable, but I don't want to have to spend the time to-- I want it to act as if it
was all initialized to zero.

But I don't want to take
the time to actually do the initialization. That might take longer
than my whole program.
So what's the secret? And so the secret is--

OK, well, we can call
this sparse, I guess.

And then I have another
array over here called dense.

And so what happens is I look at
this element-- whatever it is.

And I know how many
elements I've already seen.
So I have another counter S as-- S is the size--

how many things. Initially, there's
nothing in dense. And initially, S is 0.

So what I'm going to do is
I'm going to put 0 here,

and I'm going to put 3142
here in position 0 advanced.

And since S was zero, no
matter what I fetched here,

I know it'll be the first time. Well, I mean, maybe next
thing I put something here

in position 1618. And so I put a 1 there,
and I put 1618 here.

And then do more
computation and say, OK, now let me look at 3142.
Well, I look at 3142. It has the number 0 in it. I check zero. Yeah, that matches.

So that's good. So now, I do some
more calculation.

What's another number I
might want to do here? 2718 or something like this. I might want to probe 2718,
and I look in 2718, oh, I see--

there's a 1 in there. But I look in position 1,
and it doesn't say 2718.

So that didn't work. So I know that I've
got to put two here, and I've now got two items.

So the main idea
is then I have--

I can use all these guys. And whatever I read, there's
going to be something in there,

and I'm going to reject
that unless it points to something less than S
and the dense array confirms

that it was actually something
that I did [INAUDIBLE]. OK. So this is the trick. And it got to be called
the sparse array trick.

So sometime during the '80s, I
got around to revising my book,

The Art of Computer
Programming, Volume I, and the third edition didn't
come out until 25 years ago.

But at that time, I did have
the exercise on page 307

here called the
sparse array trick. So "Suppose you want to use a
large array for random access,

although you won't
actually being referred to very many of its entries. You want A k to be 0
the first time you exit,

but you don't want to spend the
time to set every location to 0. Explain how it's possible
to read and write

any desired elements-- A of k, reliably, given k,
without assuming anything

about the actual
initial memory contents. Doing only a small fixed number
of additional operations per

array axis." I got a question back here. Yeah. Yeah. Maybe a basic question. In your example, let's
say, at the next step,

I want to write 0
to location 999. 999? Yeah. What would I do?
OK. Now, in location 999, Yes. All right.

So here it is. And I look at 999, and I
fetch whatever is in there.

[INAUDIBLE] OK. [INAUDIBLE] Now, whatever is in there,
if it's bigger than two,

then it's got to be bad. Sure. If it's less than two, I
can check to see if it's OK.

OK. So let me write
down the algorithm.
So let's say read k OK.

What does that mean? So I said, set r to
sparse of k, all right?

And then I say, if r less
than S and dense of r--

can you read that equals
k return data of--

I'm going to have another
array data here where
I actually put stuff.

So return data, OK. Otherwise, I set sparse of
k to S and dense of S to k.

And I'm also going
to put back of--

I keep another array
back in case somebody wants me to restore memory to
the way it was before this.

Not necessary, but
maybe they want it. So back of S to r, to
S plus 1, and return 0.

So this is an integer
subroutine OK, and so it returns 0 the
first time something comes--

and so income 999-- whatever it is, it's not
going to pass this test.

And so we're going to
set sparse of k is 999.

So we're going to set sparse
of 999 to S, which is 3. And then we're going to set
dense of s to k, which is here.

And we're going to
back of s to whatever that number was in there, x999.
And then s is now equal to 4.

OK? So thanks for the question. And of course, that's
what the answer--

one of the things about my
book is it does have answers. And so in the answer, it
mentioned that, by the way,

you could also back up
to the original condition
if you wanted to. OK, now, that was 50 years ago.

Something else
happened 25 years ago, and that was a
paper that came out.

So this is 1993, a
paper that came out

by Preston Briggs and
Linda Thorson at Rice. And they're working
on compilers.

And they had
developed an extension

of these ideas that
turned out to be important in their
compiler implementation.

And so here it says, "Inspired
by a memorable homework

problem of Aho, et al. problem 2.12, we developed a
sparse set representation that

supports all the required
operations efficiently." OK, so in other words,
homework problems actually

do get noticed somehow. And so people were
getting the idea.

But their application
was different. They weren't really faced
with a billion word array

that they wanted. They didn't want to initialize. They really wanted to represent
just a subset of a universe.

And so they weren't
interested in what's in this billion word array.

They're just interested in
which parts of the array have we actually used so far.

So in other words, they didn't
need the data part here, or they only wanted to know this
list here of the dense stuff.

But they gave
basically the algorithm

that I just wrote
down, except that we didn't have to store
anything or return zero. And then they did something
new because their compiler

needed it. And that is on the next page,
they had a delete operation. A deletion is something that
Aho, Hopcroft, and Ullman

did not talk about
and neither did I. And so they said,
well, we can also
remove stuff that was there. So let me skip to--

well, actually, I'm searching
for the right permutation here.

So let me skip now to the book
that I published last year.

And this is-- ta-da-- Art of Computer
Programming, Volume 4B.

It makes a wonderful
Christmas present. [LAUGHTER] And I just learned today
that the Japanese translation

has been finished and will
be published in two weeks. And so the Korean and
Chinese translations

are going to be second
and third in this race.
But, OK, so now, I think-- let's see where am I?

On page 40 here, so
here, I'm talking about combinatorial
algorithms and how

to represent sets of things when
you want to undo your operation

as well as do things. So when we're solving
combinatorial problems,

it's basically we're
searching for a lot of needles

in a huge haystack. And so we look at parts of
the tree of possibilities.

And we have sets
of possibilities that grow and shrink,
but they start out

with lots of possibilities that
we narrow down the possibilities

after a while. But after we've
explored that part, then we have to go back
to a larger set again.

So in these
applications, we start with a set that contains the
whole universe instead of the--

which started with a
set that was empty. Now, we're starting
with the entire set,

and we delete
stuff periodically. And this is something
that Briggs and Torshion

did that wasn't done
before they did they
deleted instead of inserted. And so here's the idea.

Let's suppose that we have a
set with four things in it. I got 3, 9, 1, and 4.
And so here's the set. It's just listed sequentially.

But in another array, we've
got pointers to this one.

So 1 points to
where 1 is stored, 3 points to where 3 is stored,
9 points to where 9 is stored,

and 4 points to
where 4 is stored. It's like this dense array that
we had before, sparse and dense.

I mean, the bottom one
is sparse and the top one is the dense version. And so now, let's suppose
we want to delete 9.

So if we delete 9, we
can see where 9 is,

but we can swap 9 with the 4. So move the 9 over
here and bring the 4

to where the 9 was and then
just move the tail back. So you can see by
deleting, we do

a swap in there and everything
works, zip, zip, zip.

So that's the idea of deletion. And I'm going to work out
an example in some details

in order to make
it clearer, I hope. So in this
application then, I've
got a universe of possibilities.

And at every point, I
want to be representing

some subset of that universe. And people who work in the
combinatorial algorithms,

they call it the domain. So I have an example where
the domain has five elements.

So I have DOM is an array
that has five entries.
And I also have another array. I'll call it IDOM.

And each of these
contains a permutation

of the possible
elements of the domain. So here, I'm considering
that a domain is

some subset of 0, 1, 2, 3, 4. And I've got all
these numbers here,

and I haven't told
you what they mean. So this is DOM of 0. This is DOM of 1.

This is DOM of 2. These are the
identity permutations. So it just happens that we start
out everything DOM of 0 is 0.

DOM of 1 is 1, and so on. And then I have s which is the
total size of the domain, which

is 5. And so now, let's
suppose I delete 1.

So that means I can swap 1 with
4 and bring the 4 over here.

That's DOM now. Well IDOM is the
inverse permutation.

Well, it turns out the inverse
of this permutation is the same.

The examples will
become clearer soon. But now, S equals 4.

So indicate that by putting a
vertical line at position S.

Now, in order to make
it a little more clear, let's try to delete 4 now.

So at this point, I'm going
to switch to 4 with the 3.

And S is going to go down to 3. And the inverse
permutation, well, so 0
is still in position 0. 4 is now in position 3. 2 is still in position 2.
3 is in position 1. And 4 is in position 3. Whoops. 1 is in position 4.

So this is the
inverse permutation.

So in other words, the
first S elements of DOM,

these are the
elements of our set. And then the other elements
that aren't in our set

are listed afterwards. It's a permutation. So then, I say, well,
where does 0 appear?
0 appears right in position 0. Where does 1 appear? It occurs in position 4.

Where does 2 appear,
3 appear, and so on? So if I want to test
whether 4 is in the set,
I look at IDOM of 4, which is 3.

And it's not in the set because
it's bigger than or equal to S.

So I'll do another example, and
then write down the algorithm.

Pretty soon, you'll see
why it's very simple. So if I delete 2,
all I have to do

is move that line
one space to the left because I don't have
to swap anything.
OK, delete 0.  Delete 0.

I'm going to have
to switch 3, 0.
OK.  S is now 1.
And so 0 is in position 1. 1 is in position 4. 2 is in here.
3 is 0. 4 is 3. All right? So that's the idea.
But the beauty that-- the beautiful thing is undelete.
Suppose I say undelete 0.

I can do that by just shifting--
by just changing S and shifting

this to the right. I don't get back to the-- if I undelete 0, I'm sitting
here with 0, 3, 2, 4, 1.
1, 4, 2, 0, 3. But now, S is 2.

I'm not back at
what I had before. I'm sorry. This is 3, 0.

I don't change
anything except the S.

So I don't change anything
except the cut off. And so I've got the
same set I had here,

but it's not exactly
the same representation because every subset has
many representations.

And so the beauty is
undeletion is trivial.

I mean, you just change S. So if
I want to undelete 0, 2, and 4,

I can undo all of
these three things. I don't change anything
except change S back to 4.

And here, it's going
to be 3, 0, 2, 4. So you see the numbers
to the right of this bar

show the things that I
took out in the order that I took them out. And if I move the
bar, I get back

to the same set of
elements I had before. The set of elements doesn't
appear in any particular order.

And I could have started this
whole process with 0, 1, 2, 3,

4. I'm sorry. I could have started this whole
process with 3, 0, 2, 4, 1

and 1, 4, 2, 0, 3. Any permutation and its inverse,
I could have started that

and say that's my representation
of the entire domain.

So as the algorithm proceeds,
these numbers in here

do a little dance. And the importance
of this was first recognized 10 years ago in
this paper that came out--

this is 2013, "Sparse-Sets
for Domain Implementation."

And I really want
to meet this guy because he's got the most
interesting name I've ever

seen-- Vianney le Clement
de Saint-Marcq. And then Pierre
Schaus, Christine--

she's my friend who told
me about this paper-- and Christophe Lacoutre, who
wrote one of the main books

on constraint satisfaction. And so these people are
in Belgium and France.

And they noticed that this idea
that had come up in connection
with sparse-sets 20-- sorry, 30 years ago.

What actually
happened was I think

they discovered
it independently, and then they were
showing it to people. And they say, oh, yeah, this
is the same as what people

were calling sparse-sets. So I write out the algorithm,
and we can see what it means.

So delete k says
set r to IDOM of k.

In other words, I want
to delete element k. So I say, where does k
sit in the DOM array?

So IDOM of k tells
me where k appears. Then, it says if r is
greater than or equal to s,

return because it's
not in the domain. If it's sitting-- if r is
to the right of that line,
it's not in the current domain. So we can't delete it. Otherwise, s is s minus 1.

And we look at DOM of s. So we look at the guy who
is in that position now
that's going to be leaving us. And we change DOM of r to l.

And IDOM of l to r
because this preserves

the inverse permutation. And then, we also
keep track of what's

going on for the larger
elements IDOM of l.
Whoops. DOM of s is k.

And IDOM of k is s. So you can check that
that's what I did in this.
Now, that's dancing cells.

Let me, let me show you what
it was like with dancing links.

So dancing links was intended to
solve the same kind of problem where we want to keep
track of domains.

And in dancing links, we started
out with all five possibilities.

And these were kept in
little nodes in the computer. And they were pointing to each
other with a doubly linked list.

Well, I actually put
a header node in here.

So everything pointed to the
guy in front and the guy after.
And so there's a header node.

And then after the header
node, this points to this. This points to this.

This points to this. Now, when I deleted 1, in
this case, what happens?

Well, we still got
the header node. And 0 is here, but 0
doesn't point to 1 anymore.

0 points over to 2 and
2 points back to 0 now.

But we still have the doubly
linked list connecting, OK?

And I'll delete-- I'll do one more deletion. This was the way
dancing links work.

So if I deleted 4, then 3 is
now going to point off here.

And this guy is going to
point back not to 4 but to 3.
And these-- 2 points to 3.

And-- sorry-- 0 points to 2. 2 points to-- OK. And the idea-- when we
were doing dancing links,

the idea was to be
unclean, to be sloppy,

not to clean up our act. So after 1 was deleted,
1 still is pointing to 2

as its successor. And it's still pointing
to 0 as its predecessor. And after 4 was deleted,
4 is still pointing here.

So that when I want
to do an undelete, it's easy to do an
undelete because I

know exactly which
pointers I have to change when I'm undeleting. And that was the idea
of dancing links.

With dancing cells, though,
undeletion is even faster

because I don't have to-- I only have to change one number
to undo a whole set of deletion.

OK, so this is the difference
between dancing links

and dancing cells. And in both cases,
we're sort of using--

OK, both cases, first of
all, are extremely simple. The algorithms are
only a few lines long.

Secondly, we almost did-- in the '60s, we almost did this,
but in the '60s, I didn't do

dancing links because
after I deleted something, I also was afraid to have these
other access pointers sitting

around there. So I zeroed them out. And I found out that if
I didn't zero it out,

it wasn't going to
be garbage collected. And I was going to be able to
do everything zip-zip later on.

So with the dancing
cells, the new idea is that we keep track
of what's going on

to the right of the
bar, the elements bigger than s in the array.

We don't ignore those. We keep them up-to-date. We keep an inverse permutation
going all the time.

And then we're in good shape. OK, so now, I'm going
to go and show you

more exactly what's happening. But first, some
questions I can answer? Yeah, way in the back.

Yeah? Well, you get two. Yeah, so I'm wondering whether
for other set operations,

like unions and intersections,
if you're-- for unions and intersections, if you're
willing to do them in place.

I'm sorry, I can't hear you. I'll yell louder. For unions and intersections,
if you're willing to do--

Union and intersections? Yeah, yeah. Can you get those
pretty efficiently if you're willing
to do them in place? It's possible to do
union and intersection,

but the application I'm
talking about we don't care. Yeah.

The complement, no. But difference, yes. Wait, for complement, you
can just store the direction?

Complement with respect
to the universe, that's-- well, I guess you could--

Yeah, you just
[? saw ?] the direction. The other way around. Yeah. Yeah. That's a good point. Yeah, no, that's true. The complement,
Briggs and Torshion

didn't know how
to do complement, but now, we do because we
have the inverse, right? Yeah, OK.

What if, like,
let's say you had-- you wanted to-- I still can't hear you. I'm sorry.

Let's say that you wanted
to make like a positive set instead of-- so you initially
delete everything from your set,

but you do it in basically
the reverse frequency order. So if you think that you're set.

Start again. OK. Let's say you started
with everything-- Yeah. --and then you delete elements
in a particular order--

Yeah. --based on their
inverse frequency. So if an element is
very likely to appear

or be added to
your set, then you want to delete that last, right? Because then the undelete
operation would be very quick.

I have some other
process controlling-- telling me what to delete.

Yeah. The data-- here, I'm
talking about whatever

that heuristic is, this is
the internal representation.

OK. So I can build other
things around this.
Yeah. OK. Yeah. Right. There's a question back here.
Yeah, well, I'm back here. Wow. Back row. Yeah.

Well, yeah. If you want to delete--
if you delete a, b, c-- Yeah. --and then undelete b-- Yeah.

No, no-- You have to do the
swapping, right? It's always last in, first out. OK. Yeah.
No, there is a way to-- that's called insertion.

Yeah. Yeah. OK. [INAUDIBLE] All right, yeah, I'm
glad for these questions.

And the people who ask
questions, by the way, have priority for
the book signing. So now, I want to talk about
the context of this whole thing.

So why am I
interested in domains? And, you know-- so
the general context is

solving combinatorial problems. And by that, I mean by
combinatorial problem,

I sort of mean find all
arrangements of objects

in a very general sense. And so a combinatorial problem
is somehow arrangements.

And I know three good ways to
define a combinatorial problem.

So a good way to define
an interesting class
of arrangements. And by good, I mean declarative.

I mean, I want to say
what the arrangements are

without giving the method that
I'm going to have to do it. But defining this
means to formalize,

you know, to make a model,
some kind of, you know,

encoding of, of the
problem, explaining exactly what it means.

So I know three good
ways to encode or make

a model of combinatorial
problems in a way that's declarative instead
of imperative.

I declare what the problem is
and let the computer figure out how to solve it. And one of the main ones--

each of these has a
three-letter mnemonic. And constraint satisfaction
problem is one of them--
is one of these mnemonics. And that's what CSP stands for.

And this means that we have-- that our model has variables,
and each variable has a domain.

And then we have
constraints, which are relations between the
values of the variable.
That's the first. This next one called SAT.

This is for satisfiability. And this is the
special case of CSP

when all the domains
are just boolean. Every variable has just
two possible values,

while the CSP allows
denary things.

In fact, it also allows
continuous and infinite domain. But that's way beyond me.

I'm a finite guy. And the third way is XCC, which
is exact covering with colors.

Now, XCC, I didn't
write it very good.

XCC is the new kid on the block. It isn't as well known
as the other two. In fact, as of today, it still
doesn't have a Wikipedia page.

I think that something
else entirely, if you do Google
for XCC, which is

a shame because half of my
book, Volume 4 is about XCC.

So I'm waiting for
people to realize

what a great thing this is. But anyway, I don't
have time to wait. I have to write more books.

But-- and, you know, I
might give one more lecture

trying to popularize it. But anyway, sooner
or later, people will realize that XCC is
a really important idea.

And each of these is
sort of equal power. I can take any CSP,
and I can encode it--

I can convert it to a SAT
problem in several ways. I can convert it to an XCC
problem in several ways.

And similarly, a XCC problem
I can represent as SAT. I can represent it
as a CSP, whatever.

But each coming to a problem,
some of them are best as SAT.
Some of them are best XCC. Some are best as CSP. And the purpose of this--

well, let me just show you. I've got 450
exercises in here that

give examples of why you'd
want to know something-- why XCC is a great model.

And so let's see, the
exercises start here. So I just paged--

I start paging through. If you zoom out
a little bit, you

can see that from the
pictures that there's a lot of variety of the
kind of problems you have

that were modeling
with XCC problem. And let's see, I said 450.

So these are lots of
different kinds of problem.

And this is only the
tip of the iceberg.
It ends with puzzles.

compatible options. And so an option
is a set of items.

So, well, for example, we're

The items are, like, Joe,

And items are either
primary or secondary.

So we have a primary item
and a secondary item.

And the name XCC said
exact covering with colors.

The difference between
a primary item--

OK, so you list your options. And your problem is to
choose among these options

so that every primary item
is covered exactly once. So there's exactly one
chosen option for every item.

So if I'm trying to
match people to jobs, then every person gets
a job, and every job has been assigned to a person.

OK, so then, the secondary
item, however, has a color.

you don't have to have-- that secondary item doesn't have
to be in any of the options. But whatever options
it does appear,

it has to always
have the same color.

So the primary option
says, you know, this is the option that uses me.

The secondary option says,
these are the flavors in which I can appear.

So you think of a
crossword puzzle where the primary items are
the words across and down,

or the secondary items are
the letters that are entered.

And so if one of

the downward has

to put an x in that same cell. So the second area, the x
is the color of the thing.

items appear in options,

So the MCC problem
says that instead of saying that every primary
item has to be covered exactly

say every primary item has to be covered at least A
times and at most B times.

And this opens up a large
number of other problems.
